Description: Full-size bronze axe-head: with wide butt, incurved sides and slightly convex cutting edge. The piece was quite roughly finished and well used. Distinct hammer marks are present on the sides and on one of the faces, and the cutting edge is blunted through heavy wear. The blade has been cleaned of corrosion product. There is considerable pitting on one face. The same face bears a hieroglyphic inscription crudely chased. The blade is attached by means of a leather thong to a straight wooden haft with faceted sides.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt) (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Radiocarbon analysis has indicated that the wood is ancient (c. 2010± 130 bc) but not contemporary with the blade. Bibliography: Hilton Price, ‘Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute’ 13 (London,1884), 5; Budge, E. A. W. Budge in 'Archaeologica: or Miscellaneous Tracts relating to Antiquity' 53 (London, 1892), 91, pl. III, fig. 4; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tools and weapons : illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London' (London, 1917), 9, pl. II, 93; E. A. Wallis Budge 'A Guide to the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Egyptian Rooms, and the Coptic Room' (London, 1922), 202, 30; Y. Yadin, ‘The Art of Warfare in Biblical Lands’ I (New York, Toronto & London, 1963), 184-5; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 112,G-X/I.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (121)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1989 Jan-Mar, South Florida Science Museum, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology 1989 Apr-Jun, Miami, Museum of Science, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology 1989 Jul-Aug, Jacksonville Museum of Science History, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology 1998/9 Oct-Jun, South Carolina, The Charleston Museum, Queens & Commoners of the New Kingdom 2001 26 Jun-23 Sep, Birmingham Gas Hall, Egypt Revealed
